body.p:
Pine Bluff, Ark. March 15th 1864
Sister Maggie

Your welcome letter of Feb 26th has Just came to hands. I was glad to hear all was was well when you wrote except father I was very Sorry to hear that he was not well. I know he is getting old, and that he had worked ^very hard^; he had ^had^ a great deal of trouble to pass through in this life and ^I^ cannot but feel Sorry and tears Start involuntarily ^start^ from my eyes when I hear that he is not well. I hope he will be better when these lines reaches you. Your letter found me still in Hospital and in feeble health I do not know that I am any better than where I wrote you my last letter. I was so Sick a part of the day yesterday that I feinted. though I am feeling as well this morning, as I have for Several days. I wrote a letter to father and mother on Friday last the 11th of the present month.

There is not much danger of my going into the Service again at the present time. but if I
Should get Stout I may posibly go into the Service again, but I would like to come home first, and see you all. if I can do so without fear, and be priviledged to go and come as I pleased. Otherwise I should not enjoy myself so well. I Should not like to endanger myself by coming home. The way Matters Stand there now it would not be very pleasant for me to come home unless I would have Liberty to go where I please. Whatever may have been my faults, I never was guilty of the charges prefered against me, and I feel myself even better than my perjured accusers. I have friends and have credit here; and have always had at any place, and where I have ever been. no man Stands higher for Honesty and integrity than I do in my company on Regiment. for this reason I Should not like to endanger myself by coming home. nothing though would give me more pleasure and Satisfaction than to come home to See mother and the rest of you. I have not made no great deal of money in the Service If my Captain had have lived I Should have made Something over three thousand dollars; as it is I have had

I Remain your most
affectionate Brother
John. W. Brookover
